subject: Re: [junit] JUnit/JFCUnit  vs Silk/WinRunner
msgSnippet: I wrote up a document about how several free alternatives treat typical issues you might have with UI testing, but you can extrapolate based on your
messageBody:
I wrote up a document about how several free alternatives treat typical
issues you might have with UI testing, but you can extrapolate based on
your Silk/WinRunner experience. The two primary advantages I've heard
are 1) price and 2) tighter java integration.

Link:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/java-gui-testing/files/

Direct link:
http://f2.grp.yahoofs.com/v1/IGoWQW_fG2xJEo80FVshwITI42oY3v-
RU4Ye3nso4nf8tVMtyS9RDvcNcu7XxzMby_whLMi5VKLQwzgFLNP7/
JavaGUITesting.pdf

On Aug 6, 2004, at 2:45 PM, Boris Ayrapetov wrote:

> Hello everybody,
>
> We used to test our product(Java based application with complex
> functionalities, UI, ...) with Silk and WinRunner, but currently our
> management try to adopt JUnit and JFCUnit.
> Is there any document that explains an advantage to use these tools,
> or anybody had already migrated from Silk/WinRunner to JUnit/ JFCUnit,
> and can share their knowledge.
>
> Thanks in advance,
> Boris
>
>
>
